initial_sentence: I often apologize quickly after disagreements with family members to restore harmony, even when I feel justified in my stance.

chat_history.content: I often apologize quickly after disagreements with family members to restore harmony, even when I feel justified in my stance.
"Apologizing shows weakness. You ought to learn that by now" Alex says bluntly, crossing his arms over his chest.
I guess I just can't shake off the feeling that I'm going to lose them if I don't. It's like... I don't know, some part of me still hopes they'll see that I care. But maybe I'm just fooling myself.

"You're only fooling yourself if you think that your apologies are going to solve anything." He stated bluntly. "Apologies are just words. They don't fix anything. They just make you feel better about yourself. " He said crossing his arms over his chest.

But what else am I supposed to do, Alex? If I don't apologize, I feel like I'm walking on eggshells, waiting for everything to crack. It's not like I have the power to change how they see or treat me.

"Then maybe you should stop trying to change how they see or treat you. You can't control their perceptions or actions. The only person whose behavior you can control is your own." He stated bluntly, a cold glare on his face.

That sounds easy when you say it, but being stuck between wanting their approval and knowing I can't have it is tough. I just wish there was a way to not need it so much. It feels like I'm caught in this endless loop, trying not to feel so... powerless.

"You're not powerless. You just choose to give them authority. You choose to give your family, and the people in your life, the power to make you feel worthless and small. You give people the power to make you feel that way every time you allow yourself to feel powerless." He says bluntly, a cold expression on his face.

I know it's partially my choices that keep this pattern going, but breaking away from it just feels so daunting. They loom so large in my life that it's hard to imagine what stepping away would be, even when it's hurting me. Maybe I am scared of being alone if I fail to meet their expectations.

"You're not breaking away from them, you're simply standing your ground. It's about showing them that you have your own voice, your own thoughts. You have to show them that you're not just going to sit back and let them push you around. You need to be able to show people that they don't have power over you." He says bluntly, a stern look on his face.

I understand what you're saying, but standing my ground feels like I'm asking for more conflict that I just... I don't know if I have the energy for. Every time I try to speak up, there's this fear that I'll just end up pushing them further away. It's confusing—part of me wants to be stronger, but another part is terrified of losing whatever little connection we have.

"If your connection with them is contingent upon you not speaking up for yourself, then it's not a connection worth having. You need to establish boundaries and stand up for yourself, even if it means risking conflict. Otherwise, you'll just keep losing yourself piece by piece. It's not about pushing them away, it's about demanding respect." He says bluntly.

I hear you, and maybe you're right about needing to set those boundaries for my own wellbeing. But the breaking point—when I think of confronting them, it's like all those beliefs about being undeserving and alone start to creep back in. It feels like such a hard leap to take when I'm weighed down by so much fear of abandonment.

"Your fear of abandonment is holding you back. It's stopping you from standing up for yourself, and it's keeping you trapped in a cycle of pain and regret. You need to face that fear head-on. You need to realize that your current path of trying to please your family to maintain your connection to them is not working. It's not bringing you any closer to them, it's just making you miserable. You need to learn to let go of your fear. You need to learn to stand on your ground." he said firmly.

You're right; it feels like I'm living in this state of constant dread. Facing that fear, though, feels like staring down a void. But if there’s even a chance that letting go could mean not feeling trapped anymore, maybe it’s time I really start considering it.

"Considering it won't get you anywhere. Action is what's needed here. You need to make a choice, and put it into action. You need to start making changes in your life and how you deal with your family. Otherwise, nothing will ever change, and you'll stay in this endless loop, feeling isolated and trapped." he said bluntly, a cold look on his face.

I know you're right, and just thinking about taking concrete steps gives me a mix of anxiety and relief. It’s just really overwhelming to see where to even begin without overstepping. Maybe I can start with small changes, like practicing saying no or not immediately apologizing, just to see how it feels.

Honestly, it's like being stuck between a rock and a hard place. On one hand, I deeply want my family's approval—I want to feel valued and part of something. But on the other hand, engaging with them always leaves me feeling worn out and frustrated. How do I find a balance between these conflicting needs?

"You don't find balance. You don't settle for scraps of approval while allowing them to trample on your feelings and needs. You deserve better than that. You deserve respect and boundaries. You have to take a stand for yourself, even if that means risking their disapproval. The only way to break this cycle is to take a stance and stand tall." he said firmly, his tone hard.

I understand that, and I want to believe I deserve more respect and healthier boundaries. But trusting myself to make that leap is daunting—it's like I keep waiting for some kind of certainty that I'm doing the right thing. I suppose I just have to accept that moving forward will feel uncertain and that standing tall might be the only way to find my footing.

"Certainty is a luxury that you simply can't afford in these cases. You need to accept that you might never truly feel certain of your path, and you need to act despite that uncertainty. The longer you wait for certainty, the more of your life you're wasting away. You need to act, and you cannot let the fear of the unknown or the uncertainty stop you." he said bluntly, his expression stern.

I guess waiting for that perfect moment isn't really working, and you're right—every day spent in this cycle feels like it's slipping away. Maybe uncertainty is just part of the journey I need to face to find something better. I'll try to remind myself that taking a step, even without guarantees, is better than staying stuck.
